Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Scalable Fine-Grained Cloud Monitoring for Empowering IoT

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
We are in the age of unprecedented connectivity, where everything from computers, buildings, vehicles, medical devices, to even animals is being equipped to interact with each other by exchanging data over the Internet. This massively connected world, referred to as the Internet of Things (IoT), will play a crucial role in enabling never-before-seen computing services such as self-driving cars and personalized health care, consequently improving the quality of life. A key enabler for IoT is the cloud computing model that is already transforming computing in academia, enterprise, and the IT industry by enabling easy and on-demand access to computing resources and services at reasonable cost. Most current and future IoT applications cannot function without the infrastructure provided by cloud computing serving as the brain for controlling and processing the data from the IoT network. Thus, there is an urgent need for ensuring that the data centers that support the cloud services can sustain the ever-growing IoT needs, while maintaining high quality of services and meeting service level agreements. To this end, this project aims to undertake the fundamental task of collecting and detailed fine-grained monitoring of the health and usage statistics of rapidly growing data centers, and addresses the challenges therein.

Fine-grained data center monitoring entails that the cloud providers have to acquire, transport, store, and process exponentially increasing amount of management and monitoring data. With the amount of such data increasing at an unexampled rate of over 10 billion+ records per day, conventional acquisition and transportation schemes are no longer sufficient and efficient to handle the data tsunami. This project aims to address the problem of efficiently acquiring and transporting cloud management and monitoring data. For data it will focus on efficiently moving the data from the points it is collected inside the data center to the points where it needs to be stored for processing. Successful completion will result in tools that cloud providers can use to monitor their data centers and obtain measurements useful to predict and/or localize performance bottlenecks. Finally, the educational and outreach goals of this project include training the next-generation computer scientists with skills to manage and design innovative IoT applications and systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cloud computing model has emerged as the de facto paradigm for efficiently providing infrastructure, platform, and application services to academia, enterprise, and the IT industry. With the emergence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the model has gained even more importance because the brain behind the IoT applications that makes the things smart is often implemented in the cloud. The major goal of this project is to design innovative methods to monitor the health of cloud data center resources and optimize the usage of these resources, which is crucial for sustaining the cloud computing model in the age of IoT.

IoT devices often gather data from sensors but do not process it on-device, rather forward the data to one or more applications, often deployed in the cloud. Performance of the tenant IoT applications in the cloud is greatly impacted by the networking protocols they use. If the protocols are not chosen carefully, the applications may face significant performance degradation, leading to financial and functional losses. One of the most important protocols in the suite of networking protocols is the TCP variant that the applications use. Choosing the correct TCP variant in the cloud deployment is important because it impacts the throughput, round trip time (RTT), and response time of the applications deployed by the tenants. All of these metrics directly impact user/IoT device experience of the application. Correct choice of TCP can also lead to reduction in the overall amount of network traffic sent between the virtual machines, which in turn, would result in reduction in the revenue spent on network communication. Keeping this in view, we performed a comprehensive characterization of several modern TCP variants in Amazon's and Google's cloud platforms. We demonstrated that by just using an appropriate TCP variant in an application's compute cluster, the average throughput performance can be improved by up to 13.7% and the mean round trip time can be decreased by up to 5 times.

We further advanced our understanding of how multiple flows, controlled by different TCP variants in the cloud, impact each others' throughput and latency when they coexist on (i.e., traverse through) the same bottleneck link at the same time. This is important to study because the switch fabrics of today's data centers carry traffic that is controlled by a wide gamut of TCP congestion control algorithms. Different TCP variants employ different approaches to adjust their sending rates in response to packet losses and/or changes in RTT. Therefore, the flows of some TCP variants naturally capture more bandwidth compared to the others, which, in turn, translates to longer job completion times and degradation of the performance achieved by the network applications that are using the disadvantaged TCP variants. We have demonstrated that if the workloads (both IoT as well as non-IoT) are placed such that different workloads using different TCP variants never (or as infrequently as possible) coexist at bottleneck links, it would not only lead to minimal waste of networking resources but would also enable workloads to utilize the cloud's infrastructure more fairly.

In addition to the outcomes mentioned above, this project has also resulted in several other methods and artifacts. For example, we have proposed data structures to accurately record and transport telemetry data in the cloud, optimized the access link utilization for IoT networks, and developed scalable data management service frameworks. The research results from this project have been published in top-tier computer science conferences and journals, including ACM/IEEE SC, IEEE Cluster, IEEE ICDCS, IEEE ICNP, IEEE BigData, USENIX FAST, ICCCN, IFIP NETWORKING, IEEE Transactions on Networking, and IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems. The key concepts, methods, and algorithms that we have developed will potentially motivate more research work from the community in this area to refine and extend them further for IoT and cloud computing in various IoT verticals.

Through this project, the students have learnt how to develop and use probabilistic methods to optimize real-world resources and how to implement and optimize various communication protocols in the cloud. They have also learnt how to deploy, execute, and evaluate various applications on public clouds. These skills will be very helpful to the students when they pursue careers in academia, national laboratories, industry, and other research setups after their graduation. This, in turn, will contribute towards building a skilled workforce for the nation. The PIs have also incorporated several modules and course projects based on this project into their undergraduate and graduate courses.
